awd_titl_txt: Social Status-dependent regulation of an identified brain circuit
awd_abstract_narration:
Social hierarchies are organizing agents for all social animals. They allow the peaceful yet unequal division of natural resources based on the dominance rank of group members. As social hierarchies mature, animals begin to alter their behavior according to their social rank. This project advances understanding of the neural mechanisms that underlie social aggression and how social experience shapes animal behavior based on social rank. Using zebrafish as a model organism and an integrative approach of behavioral, cellular, including electrophysiological, and molecular analysis, the investigators study how social experience regulates identified brain centers involved in modulation of behavioral output according to their social rank. Specifically, investigators study how social status is encoded in brain and the mechanisms through which it regulates the startle escape response.  Zebrafish are an ideal model organism to address these key questions because they are highly social animals and form stable dominant-subordinate relationships that can readily be investigated. Moreover, zebrafish can be modified genetically to pinpoint specific pathways that control specific motor responses.  Results from this project will provide a better understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying social aggression and how social information is encoded within the brain to alter motor activity. In addition, the project provides extensive research experiences for undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds, as well as includes science educational activities for middle and high school students.

This project investigates the interplay between hypothalamic dopaminergic nuclei and their modulation of the Mauthner neural circuit that underlies escape responses in zebrafish. The Mauthner neurons are a single pair of reticulospinal neurons activated by auditory stimuli and innervate contralateral spinal motor neurons. Supra-threshold stimuli activate the Mauthner neurons and leads to the startle response. The startle response is also prone to descending dopaminergic (DA) modulatory input from the hypothalamus. Building on evidence that DA plays an important role in social aggression, motivation, and stress, this project investigates the mechanisms by which DA controls escape behavior in animals of different social status.  To this end, a combination of molecular, electrophysiological and calcium imaging, histological, genetic, pharmacological, and behavioral approaches are utilized.  Additionally, the project examines the role of nuclear progestin receptor in regulating dopaminergic activity.  Hypothalamic DA neurons express the nuclear progestin receptor (Pgr), a transcriptional factor that regulates expression of target genes involved in hormonal regulation. Prompted by preliminary data indicating a regulatory role of Pgr on DA pathways, experiments are undertaken to elucidate the underlying neural and hormonal signals that determine social regulation of the descending dopaminergic input to the Mauthner escape circuit.  Collectively, the studies will advance understanding of the mechanisms that underlie modulation of behavior by social information.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Aggression is a universal behavioral feature that is present in almost all social animals.  It serves as an important organizing agent for the formation of social relationships and division of limited resources. As social relationships mature, the behavior of group members shift according to their social rank; dominants display their high rank with displays signifying their status while subordinates display submissive-like behavior to signify their low rank. Despite its basic biological relevance, our understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying dominance relationships and how they affect brain structure and function remains poorly understood. This is due, in part, to the complexity of the brain and variability of behaviors animals can display which are often highly context dependent. This project was motivated to understand how brain circuits alter their activity in social animals with stable dominance hierarchies. Our motivation stemmed from the fact that although social-status-dependent differences in behavior must arise due to differences in brain function, status-dependent differences in the underlying neural circuitry are poorly described. To address this knowledge gap, we utilized zebrafish to investigate how agonistic interactions between zebrafish affect the function and cellular interaction of two brain circuits that allow animals to integrate sensory social cues and relay them downstream to the spinal cord to allow animals to adapt their behavior as they socially rise or fall within their social structure. Zebrafish are vertebrate animals that are highly social, and they share similar structural and functional brain organization with other vertebrates and mammals. They interact aggressively and form stable dominance relationships. Prior work from our lab showed that as dominance relationships mature, the behavior of zebrafish changes dramatically according to their social rank. Dominant fish increase their swimming activity to signify territorial displays and reduce their startle escape responses. Conversely, subordinates reduce swimming to avoid interacting with the dominants and increase their escape activity when startled. Based on this simple behavioral observation, we conducted series of experiments to determine the neural mechanisms that underly these behavioral differences.

        Initially, we focused on examining the role of dopamine in mediating these behavioral adaptations. Dopamine has been implicated in social aggression, motivation, and depression in many animals including humans. It is also involved in regulating brain circuits that control motor activity. Through series of experiments, we discovered that a specific hypothalamic nucleus is socially regulated in that amount of dopamine synthesized and released and how signaling is interpreted by other circuits is dictated by social status. Although the amount of dopamine released in both dominants and subordinates is similar, the pattern of how it is released onto other neurons ultimately shifts motor circuits activity and how ultimately the animals react to sensory social cues. In addition, we discovered that spinal circuits involved in regulating the escape and swim behaviors alter their expression of which dopaminergic receptor type they express. So doing transforms their interpretation of the released dopamine and ultimately how animals behave. Through a series of pharmacological and histological experiments, we discovered that subordinates reduce expression of one specific type of dopamine receptor in a particular class of spinal cord neurons compared to dominants. This targeted reduction promotes subordinates to produce more escape behavior at the expense of swimming; thus, allowing them to adapt according to their social rank.

        With this in mind, we sought to determine how social cues affect the animals’ behavior and whether miscues can influence dominance formation and disrupt behavioral activities. Zebrafish change their body colors during social interactions to signify dominance. We discovered that body color becomes darker in dominants and lighter in subordinates. These social cues serve to signify the animals’ social rank. When we disrupted these visual cues by using albino zebrafish that lack coloration, zebrafish were unable to form stable dominance relationships, aggressive activity increased dramatically, swim and escape behavior patterns and brain physiology were significantly disrupted.

        We extended on our discoveries and conducted a series of experiments to determine whether the behavioral and neurophysiological differences observed can be reversed if animals were provided an opportunity to socially rise within their group or forced to submit to more aggressive members. We discovered that animals are quick to adapt both behaviorally and physiologically as their social environment evolves. In a final set of experiments, we discovered that changes in behavior patterns can be altered pharmacologically by manipulating the dopaminergic system in such a way that subordinates can be induced to behave more like dominants while dominants can be induced to behave submissively by activating/deactivating specific dopaminergic pathways. Collectively, the project provided new insights of how social conditions influence brain structure and function and hold promise in improving our understanding of the neurophysiology of human social interactions and behavior. Funding provided support to train two PhD students, eight master students, fourteen undergraduates (58% were of underrepresented groups in STEM research).
